terms.definition: Managed Service Provider - a company that remotely manages a customer's IT infrastructure and end-user systems on a proactive basis
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A web-hosted system that allows teams to create, store, manage, and collaborate on documentation from anywhere with internet access
The implementation and management of quality IT services that meet the needs of the business through people, processes, and technology
The ability to supervise and track IT systems, networks, and devices from a distant location using specialized software tools
Software that is installed and run on the user's own servers or infrastructure rather than on a third-party cloud service
Security measures that determine who can view, edit, or manage specific documents and resources within a system
The combination of programming languages, frameworks, tools, and technologies used to build and run an application or system
Standard Operating Procedure - a set of step-by-step instructions compiled to help workers carry out routine operations consistently
A collaborative website or platform that allows multiple users to create, edit, and organize content collectively
Software whose source code is freely available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute
The systematic process of tracking, maintaining, and optimizing an organization's physical and digital assets throughout their lifecycle
Remote Monitoring and Management - software tools that allow IT professionals to monitor and manage client systems remotely
Iterative project management and software development methodologies that emphasize flexibility, collaboration, and rapid delivery
User Interface - the visual elements and interactive components through which users interact with a software application
